Everything you need to know about this amazing device:

[...]

Done and done.
Defenitely a step up from the last generation(which I think was already a 5/5)

**REVIEW UPDATED ON 7/30/13 - Updated speakers, "other features", battery life, gripes**

For anyone on the fence, and especially for those frustrated by the performance slowdown issues with the original Nexus 7 tablet, don't let that scare you off from buying the second generation model.

Google made all of the right improvements to the product, and the result is a significantly improved product for a marginally higher cost. Only time will tell if this unit suffers the same performance fate as the original model (for those not familiar, over time, the first generation tablets tended to quickly slow down and struggle to perform even basic tasks like browsing the internet). However, Android 4.3 feels ultra-smooth so far, and I am hoping that Google and Asus learned from their original mistakes.

SCREEN: The new screen is absolutely stunning. Some people argue that the resolution of 323 pixels per inch is unnecessary, but you can really see the difference when you use it in person. Text is significantly sharper and a little easier on the eye to read. Using the tablet to watch videos and see pictures produces a stunning result.

PROCESSOR: This is the #1 reason I'd recommend this new, upgraded Nexus 7 over the older version. The speed upgrade is unquestionably immense, and to those who have used the older and newest model Nexus 7, you will notice and appreciate this immediately. Apps load instantly; the internet browsing experience is smooth and a very welcome upgrade over past performance. It's strange; a few days ago I was satisfied with the decent albeit declining performance of my 1st Gen Nexus 7. Now that I have this new one, I use them both side by side and the older model feels like a dinosaur. This alone is reason enough to upgrade.

SIZE/WEIGHT: The reduced thickness and weight of the tablet is very noticeable. I often times used my old Nexus 7 tablet while sitting in bed, to check email and browse the web prior to going to sleep. Holding the old Nexus in one hand, and the new one in the other, the differences in size and weight are VERY noticeable. No doubt will provide a more comfortable long term usage experience, especially for extended sessions while on flights or the subway.

BATTERY LIFE: After a couple days of using this new Nexus 7, I can confidently say that the battery life has been significantly improved over the original model. My previous session of about 2 hours straight of use (screen on, using apps that draw semi-frequent data over wi-fi) drained only 20% of the battery life. If I project this out, it would tell me that I could get 10 hours of constant use on one full charge. I haven't run through an entire charge yet from 100% down to 0% (I've been recharging after each use), but I'll try to get to that sometime this week and report back on my total real-world battery life.

CAMERAS: Google added a rear-facing Camera on this new second gen Nexus. While I typically wouldn't use my tablet as a camera, I have tried it out and it takes excellent pictures. Focuses quickly, the images are sharp and the low light performance, while not great, is better than I would have expected. The front-facing camera gets more use for me (I use my tablets to Skype with family). The new front facing camera is noticeably sharper and better in lower light situations than the original Nexus 7 camera was. In low light, the old model was almost unusable. The 2nd gen Nexus 7 low light performance is very acceptable.

SPEAKERS: I've now spent some time using this second-gen Nexus 7 side by side with my original Nexus 7. Separately, they both sound very acceptable for speakers from small tablets. Using them side by side, the improvements to the Nexus 7 are very noticeable, and the sound is more clear even at high volumes. I'd say that this new model sounds far less "tinny" than the original Nexus did. Personally, I don't use the built-in speakers often (I'm normally either listening with headphones, or using bluetooth audio to my Logitech Boombox). But for people who do use the built-in speakers to play music or watch movies, you will appreciate the improvement in the speakers.

OTHER FEATURES: Last night, I realized that this tablet is compatible with Qi Wireless Charging, a discovery which made me VERY happy. I use a Nexus 4 cell phone, and I keep it on my nightstand on the Google Nexus Charging Orb. I attempted to use the orb with this new Nexus 7 tablet, and it worked perfectly. You have to sit the tablet landscape, with the orb centered on the tablet, and it synced up and began charging instantly.

COMPARISONS: I will update this section shortly with my comparison review between this 2nd Gen Nexus 7, the iPad Mini, and the Kindle Fire HD, as soon as I've had more time to test them all side by side.

GRIPES AND COMPLAINTS: Here, I'll list any gripes that I have about the tablet. My first major gripe is that I am not a huge fan of the texture/material used on the back of the tablet. It's a slightly rubberized feeling coating, which I assume they did to create additional grip. However, I've been finding that after holding with one hand for a few minutes, I notice the tablet starting to slide a little bit in my hand. I think this is a combination of the new texture plus the fact that it's thinner than it used to be. I'm probably going to be purchasing a case for it shortly, which should alleviate this problem, but it is still worth noting. This is just a personal preference things (if you normally hold it landscape w/ two hands, you'll probably prefer this new texture over the old one).

All in all, I am VERY impressed with how much faster this tablet is than my original Nexus 7 tablet. As long as this model doesn't suffer the performance slowdown issue of the original Nexus 7, I don't anticipate moving this away from a 5 star product anytime soon, but only time will tell I guess. I will keep this review updated as I go, and add thoughts on more features once I test them out further (the speakers, longer term battery life tests, performance slowdown, etc). If you have anything else you want me to address, please let me know in the comments section and I will be glad to address it.

And the thin body frame makes it a breeze to hold. It is a huge improvement over previous model. It leaves a lot to be desired from other manufacturers. But the big question as of now is its reliability. So far it looks and feels great, no flaws uncovered yet. But my last year's Nexus 7 experience left a lot to be desired. (hence it is a 4 star review, not a 5 star)

Edit: stereo speakers are vast improvement, bezels are thin, screen is very responsive, no lag.

I bought the Nexus 7 in Oct. 2015 and initially liked it very much because of its great screen resolution and features.  A few days ago, it refused to boot up even though it had a sufficient charge.  I searched for help on the Internet and determined that either the battery had failed or there was a software issue that prevented it from booting up. Fortunately, I tried the tip recommended for the software issue (you hold down the power button for 30 seconds) and the Nexus 7 booted up. Replacing the battery is really hard (difficult to pry open the case), so I'm glad it wasn't the battery.  I still would recommend the Nexus 7 for its features and screen resolution, but it does has a software issue.

Purchased for OTG Netflix and Reading using my Note 4 as a hotspot, gets the job done at an affordable price ( Can't beat 100 bucks for the features this packs )

- Pure stock android, no bloat ( Comes pre-installed with a lot of Google Apps that I don't need though ), firmware is up to date ( MOB30P Marshmallow as of this post )
- Much more performance / battery friendly savings once rooted and installed with an AOSP based Custom ROM.
- Charging every other day on light use of Netflix and reading alone from 90% to 20%, and I'll be damned lucky with two and a half.
- No back light bleed ( white or red hue on a black background ) as of this post.

Hopefully no overcharging or undercharging will give the battery issues as I charge only up to 90% and let it drain to 20% before I shut off the tablet, should give me a good 2-3 Years before it won't hold a charge, never felt like it's been over heated ( 80~85F ambient room ) and the brightness has been set to 50% ( No Auto / ASB ) since purchase, love the premium feel the back of the tablet gives along with the grip it's given whilst holding it. Never needed the 32 GB's ( Double the price ) so 16 GBs of storage is fine for me.

Best Android tablet for the price, that I've seen. Excellent display, fast processor, ok sound. This is the 4th one I've purchased. I bought the 2012 model for my 12 year-old son, when they first came out. He liked it so much (so did I), that I bought my husband and myself each a Nexus, the following year. I didn't even realize at the time, that there had been so many changes made, for the 2013 model. All for the better! I actually felt guilty, because as good as my son's 2012 model was....this 2013 model knocked it flat! The only con we've seen, with either model, is that over time the charging port becomes very loose, and you have to become innovative with how you get the charger to stay plugged in and charging. We didn't encounter this problem til well after a year, though. I just ordered our 4th 2013 tablet, as another gift. 16gb has been more than enough room for my husband and I. Of that 16gb, you actually get around 12gb of storage. My husband and I each have a few game apps, and some sports, news, weather apps, and Facebook. We mostly just surf the web, and look up music on youtube. We've each only used about 8gb. However, my son downloads whole movies/videos, and has a ton of game apps and music, too, and he has had to delete stuff to free up storage for new stuff. If you plan on keeping movies or videos on your device, go with the 32gb, for sure.

I really like this tablet.  It is sleek and slim.  To me it looks as nice as the iPad mini, but much less expensive.  It is usually responsive and meets my needs.  I would recommend it to anyone looking for a 7 Android tablet.

It updates to the latest version of Android (currently 6.0.1).  The first couple of days it is constantly asking if you want to update, because it goes through each version of Android.  Once it is done, the updates become part of the factory reset so the OS does not need to update again until a new version is released.

The display is quite nice, to me.  Note that I generally don't buy high-end devices so if you are coming from one, your opinion may differ.

Reasons that I did not give five stars:
- No micro SD slot.  The 16GB is large enough for day-to-day use, but I was working on a short-term project where more space would have been nice.
- Occasionally the screen becomes less responsive and I have to touch it a few times before it will respond.  A restart fixes this issue.
- The auto-brightness setting does not work as well as Id like.  Sometimes it is too bright for conditions and other times too dim, so I manually adjust it.  I never have to adjust the auto-brightness of my Moto G (2015) phone.

Other than those three minor things, I like everything about it!

Using it for the drone FPV, it is a bit laggy at times and skips occasionally (probably a half dozen times in 3 hours of flight), which isn't a big deal for me. Bottom line - it works great, is super fast, has GPS ( GLONASS as well), Bluetooth, Wifi, everything you need in a tablet and one more thing: it's super light. I'm able to fly with this attached to the remote for an hour with my arms not even feeling it at all. It's really light, and I love that for the purposes I bought it for. This is an awesome tablet, and the price cannot be beat for the specs (go ahead, compare them yourself to 2016 tablets specs).

But I set it down, and pick it up a couple hours later and find the screen spontaneously cracked which, because the touchscreen digitizer is fused to the glass, renders the tablet useless.

The charging port is an industry standard, cheap part, but it's the weak link in all these refurbished tablets.  My real complaint is with the 3rd party seller (BuyFromUs2012) but you can only leave seller feedback for 90 days after purchase, so I'm posting a warning to any potential customers here:  Don't buy from these guys!

I think it's good to find reviews that are a little further out from just a couple weeks from purchase. So here is one a couple years from purchase.

There are many aspects about this tablet that I received as a Christmas gift in 2013. Portability. Great size. Clarity. Ease of use. Great GPS access. Accessibility to file storage missing on Apple Tablets, and much more.

However, there have been a number of disappointments along the way.

First, the device rebooted at random, incessantly, at the start. As new releases of Android rolled out, this happened with far less regularity. But it still happens. I am happier that it is less frequent now. This was very common when I bought this.

Second, the headphone jack stopped producing stereo some time ago. That is disappointing for good effect when watching videos with headphones. Bluetooth is the only way to obtain stereo with the right speakers.

Third, I find that blue tooth has a hard time connecting to devices. A Christmas present I received this past year was a wireless speaker cube. I had been unsuccessful pairing the device until I recently completed a factory reset on the tablet. Keeping my fingers crossed that this will continue to work.

Fourth, the accelerometer appears to have failed. Google Sky no longer works. Compass apps and levels (such as Bubble) no longer work. I was told this is a rare occurrence for this tablet, but it's a downer none the less. I wonder if this doesn't effect auto-tilt, which isn't always responsive.

With all these issues, I would rate the tablet with 1 or 2 stars, if I didn't still love what it can do so much.

I've had this tablet for about 18 months. My biggest complaint is that the battery drops ridiculously when not in power saver mode (which is why I turn it off after every use). It takes hours to charge this to full 100%. The 1080p screen is gorgeous to watch HD videos on. My Bluetooth speakers sound better when I play my music from this tablet rather than my iPhone. If it wasn't for the battery issues, this could've easily been 4 stars.

The same thing I use on my HDTV's.  I did order from Amazon a black Poetic case cover as it fit perfectly, is light, and when you close the cover, it automatically turns the tablet off due to a thin magnet inside of the cover. I also purchased a SlimPort HDMI adapter (display port) so I can just plug a regular HDMI cord into it and the TV to watch movies, YouTube, etc.

Finally, I just ordered a new one, that also comes with the official tablet cover, from Groupon for $119. I normally get everything from Amazon but the price has been going up recently. That in itself tells you how popular this tablet is!!!

If you are a college student, and you want an inexpensive tablet that can help you study, entertain and update news, then Nexus 7 from Google is an ideal candidate. It costs only about $150. This medium-sized tablet is very handy, lightweight, portable and has two standout features that people will love: Android Lollipop and great display.

Android Lollipop
Android Lollipop is the latest version of the Android operating system made by Google. This version brings the screen experience to the next level when your every interaction is animated. Basically every time you touch, swipe or zoom in or out, the operating system brings something to the screen; so you know exactly what just happens and where things are going. There are a lot of helpful animations enabled throughout different applications. For example, when you text your friend by typing on the virtual keyboard, there is always a small wave coming out from the center of the button you touch; it not only gives you the experience of pressing an actual button but also makes sure you hit the correct one. All the transitions or transposes are running on consistently high frame rate of 60 frames per second, which brings the smooth, intuitive and responsive interactions. A cheap table that is able to run Lollipop will bring college students both monetary satisfaction and user experience contentment.

Display
I love the Nexus 7 display. It is a 1200 by 1920 pixel panel, which give a pixel density of 320 pixels per inch. That is one of the sharpest pixel density values on the market of tablets right now, and any college student would love to Netflix and chill on this screen. Nexus 7 also has a very bright display, coming in handy with the auto-brightness feature, which is doing a great job adjusting your surrounding environment. Those high resolution and auto-brightness features give a great reading experience. You can easily bring this portable device to school and read on it without having to carry your heavy textbooks. The device size aspect of 16:9 fits perfectly with almost all the videos, from watching university lectures on Coursera to referencing tutorials on Youtube. This handy mobile device helps you a lot with studying, especially when there are a ton of flash card or tutorial applications on Google Play Store for you to download.

Nexus 7 is a very thin device, which leads to its drawback of having short battery life. However, the thinness gives us a very lightweight device at about only 0.64 pounds. Even though it has short battery life, it still lasts for about a day, which is good enough for you to do your work in school.
I highly recommend college students to try out this economical but effective mobile device. It helps you studying or relaxing anytime you need. Especially, like me, if you want to get involved in developing applications for Android, this medium-size device proves to be very useful for testing.

I bought this in September 2014 after considerable research--the full HD screen closed the deal for me. At the time, I wasn't sure if I needed a tablet, or would even like using one; it was pretty much on a whim. Well boy has my point of view changed! This thing IS my TV set.

I use it for browsing, Facebook, messaging, email, Skype, Youtube and Netflix. And it has performed excellently, always pushing HD output to the screen when other devices stall, buffer, and demand to have the resolution lowered to continue playback. Physical design is good and functional.

Today I own an Asus TF700T (another beautiful screen and amazing component quality), a Nextbook 10.1" as my "workhorse laptop", and this tablet--in addition to a tower for video editing, web design and other activities where I need more processing power and a bigger display. I would buy the Nexus 7 again; and in fact, I have as I accidentally sat on the thing a few months back and had to buy another screen. (Mental note: never put anything in your back pocket, no matter how overloaded your hands are on the way to the car. Make multiple trips: it'll cost you less.) Well worth the investment and one of the best tablets money can buy--absolutely the best in the 7-8" range...to this day.

Touch recognition just flickers all over the screen with every tap and long-press is all but impossible. Trying to type, it has started producing random triples of any keystroke and registers input from places up to an inch away from the location of the touch. When you pan the screen up or down, vertical lines appear where half of the screen will lag behind the other half instead of sliding in unison. Horribly disappointed in the product quality, especially since touch-screen sensitivity on the working tablet is in itself a major downgrade from the older model.

I have mostly Apple devices, i.e. an iPhone 6 and an iPad air. But I decided to get the Nexus 7 because I wanted a workhorse that I could beat up all day long without worrying about wear and tear, as it is less expensive to replace it, as opposed to one of my Apple devices. Not only that, I was able to benefits from the three years worth of apps that I had accumulated when I was an Android person.

I've had mine for going on 3 years now, and it's still working great. Nice sharp display, I can watch Netflix while I chop vegetables, play Algerian Patience while I'm stuck in dull meetings, read the newspaper, get my email, study French, listen to music -- an indispensable little gadget, worth much more than it costs. Easy to learn. Excellent quality!

Note: from earlier horrible experience with Apple iPad Mini, I have not yet installed the latest system upgrade for this tablet. I downloaded it a couple of years ago but did not install it. I am reluctant to interfere with a good thing -- it's working fine and I don't want to risk having a system upgrade brick my tablet the way Apple bricked the Mini with its iOS upgrade. The difference is ... this current upgrade is not being "pushed" and no one is annoying me by constantly reminding me it's there. I feel I am being treated as an adult who is the actual owner of the device and can decide whether to upgrade or not. Unlike my experiences with Apple (and Microsoft, for that matter).

The Nexus 7 2013 tablet is from Google, meaning that despite the device being older, it can still kick butt. I got the tablet for Christmas for myself since my old tablet was a $25 piece of crap. This one goes WAY faster with its two GB of RAM and a great processor. Being from Google, it updated to Android 6.0.1 out of the box and it runs great. The main camera is pretty good with 5 MP in well lit areas, but is just awful in low light. The selfie cam is only 1.2 MP and isn't very good in any lighting. The device itself feels great in your hands and is easy to hold (Mind you, I have large hands). The brilliant, bright, and HD touch screen works great and I can easily speed type or use the swype feature. Also, with Android 6, most, if not all, the iOS emojis are on the built in keyboard. Overall, I highly recommend this product to any person who needs a tablet as it is great for gaming and productivity, actually quite pretty, and is also a great deal. (I got it for $125.50)

It love this as a general use tablet. It's native Google so no messy extras like you get from Samsung or any other vendor. Very clean interface. The screen is bright and great for watching netflix or a movie on a plane or hotel. I like that it's small enough to be in my briefcase or hand while travelling yet large enough to be a serviceable table for email, surfing or watching movies etc. I often watch netflix in bed with headphone on this than use the 32" tv on the wall!

I have a larger 10.3 tablet with detachable keyboard I used to use, but it's now sitting in the corner of the room getting dusty now, so that tells me how good the Nexus 7 has been - it's pretty much replaced my laptop and larger tablet for my day to day checking of emails, etc.

I LOVE this tablet. This is my first tablet and I was getting overwhelmed delving into the countless top 10 lists, the different specs., and seemingly same features. My criteria were: 1.) something with a great resolution for watching online streaming. 2.) Something that could easily download ebooks through Nook, Axis360, and Kindle apps. 3.) Something that had a relatively simple/easy learning curve interface. It's met and surpassed all those and has practically replaced my laptop. My only issues are like other reviews, there is some light bleeding and the battery isn't as lasting as I'd like. Also, I'm very confused about how to get the screen to turn off after a certain amount of time. I've set the preference but it doesn't seem to stick, though this could probably be chalked up to my Luddite confusion.

The tablet itself is fine; that would get 5 stars.

However, after 9 months the charger port stopped working.  Tried it with about a dozen chargers and none worked.  So I contacted ASUS for a warranty repair.

Their customer service is horrendous.  An hour on the phone led to nothing except, "your serial number is invalid," or, "your warranty has expired."  Both false statements.  Submitting an online RMA results in an email that links to a broken website.  Submitting an email request on the support site leads to another email that redirects to an unresponsive link.

They keep asking for the same information over and over and will not provide an RMA number or address.  I guess their strategy is to be so frustrating that we will just go away.  They clearly do not honor or support their product or warranty promise.

Oh yeah, one more thing: their online instructions for finding the serial number are wrong.  You actually have to use a magnifying glass or microscope to read the nearly invisible number on the back of the tablet...

I got this use with a drone. The 1 major problem I'm having with it is that the GPS is not nearly as accurate as my iPhone.
The GPS is set to high accuracy in the Location settings but it still shows me to be about 80-90ft from where I really am. Even when I use other GPS apps, other than just Google Maps, and input the Lat/Long into at satellite map on the desktop/website it still shows the wrong place.
Being 10ft I could almost deal with but 90ft with a drone set to follow or orbit me is a bad thing.
The other problem with the GPS is not only is 90ft most of the time it also likes to drift a lot or jump the blue dot even further away and back again. And this is after letting the Map app sit for about 5-10 even 20 or 30 mins. Mean while compared to my iPhone that's also using Google Map app the blue dot hasn't moved and if it has it's barely anything at all.
I may have to get a bluetooth GPS receiver and hope that helps.

Speaking of the GPS, it'll suck the hell out of your battery. So keep that in mind.

I also don't know if this normal for the Nexus 7 or what but the one I got the battery was completely dead. I've never had this happen on a brand new, unopened, device until now. I own a lot of tech gadgets and they've mostly all had a charge on the better. Unless the device has a NiCd battery, then it makes sense when the battery is empty. But with a Li-ion battery there should always be at least a 50-80% charge on new devices other wise it could actually hurt the battery. So I had to let it sit and charge for about 20-30mins before it would come up. Plus it didn't help when I looked into what the 5 flashing light meant on the Nexus and see a bunch of stories of people not having their Nexus not working any more or having to do some voodoo to make it work after they have let the battery completely drain, it can be a bit of a fright.

Now this isn't a point against the Nexus itself but more against Google, which is why I didn't knock any stars off. The Nexus 7 comes with Android 4.2 (or was it 4.3, I forget, not that it matters in this case) but to update to the latest version of Android (6.01) you have to install every little update between them first. So first I had to go through all of the 4.4.x, then the 5.x and then finally 6 to get 6.01. I don't understand why they could just make the update go straight from "old" version to "latest" version.
I have yet to see anyone talk about this type of thing and it's just something I have to get out there.

Great tablet, and a huge improvement over the original model. My old 2012 no longer is fast enough to smoothly run even some of the most basic apps on Android 5. Definitely buy the 2013 version if you want a Nexus 7.

What's great:
- Screen is bright enough to be seen in outdoors weather when needed
- Comparable battery life to your phone/other tablet. I use mine heavily for productivity purposes (not video) and it lasts 2 days on a charge.
- Loud sound with built-in speakers.
- Rear camera has decent quality; front camera sucks but you really only use it for Skyping.
- Feels structurally solid.
- Has a notification LED (was missing in previous version).

Not so great:
- No external SD card slot
- With the Poetic case, the microphone picks up a lot of extra noise if you handle the device while recording or Skyping. Microphone is on the side, where you can cover it with your hand if you're not careful. Set it down on a flat surface and it picks up sound well, though.
My kid loves it. That's all that counts.

Screen resolution is great (that alone is reason to buy the 2013 over the 2012), size is great, battery life is poor, Android is increasingly privacy-invasive (despite making a show of privacy features).

This is an excellent android tablet.  I have purchased my children other tablets and I am often annoyed at how laggy they are.  Also, they constantly have to uninstall apps to install new apps.  That is also a major annoyance.  My last complaint with most tablets is that the micro usb is a fragile port.  I say that b/c most people I know, adults and children, break them! Excellent tablet ... 5 stars.  Sold back my 2012 version to Amazon for some credit and upgraded to the 2013 version which is still being made as of October 2015 (the date on my new one).  I purchased it from Amazon directly as it seems they are selling recently made versions.  It had a holiday special sale price, so for a little over hundred dollars (after sell back credit) I was able to essentially upgrade my older tablet to a brand new one after 3 years of use and hopefully get another 3 years.  This version is a tremendous price/performance value in and of itself right now, but for me, I look at it that for $325 ($200 originally paid for 2012 version plus the 2013 upgrade cost) I essentially am getting use of an amazing piece of computing power that is consistently relevant for the times - for 6 total years.  That sounds like superb value when one looks at the alternatives.  I say consistently relevant above because 1) Google is very good with releasing timely Android updates to this device and 2) it is 2016 and this device pretty much has the same hardware as from 2013 and yet it is just as competitive now in terms of performance as it was three years ago.  There's not much other tablets are doing better if arguably anything.  Although I enjoyed the earlier one, this version is much improved over the 2012 version and I highly recommend it.  It is buttery smooth with the faster processor and the 2gb of ram.  The Google ecosystem of products/services is terrific.  When combined with Android (and some excellent tablet hardware like this) one could not ask for more.  I also own a Chromebook and between Chrome OS on the chromebook, Chrome browser on windows, and Android on tablet, things just work very seamlessly across all devices.  The upgrade to Marshmallow went smoothly as device was already preloaded either Jellybean or Kitkat with two to three restarts thereafter to upgrade to Marshallow.  One restart to upgrade to Lollipop (Android v5) then another to upgrade to Marshmallow.  Also highly recommend the devicewear ridge case to go with it.  Hopefully Google continues to keep this 7-inch form factor that is the Nexus 7 product going forward in future iterations as it is clearly a winner.

It turns out Marshmallow isn't so bad. If your getting this to replace a Nexus 7 2012, I suggest you root the old unit and put Kit Kat back in as it will perform just as fast as Marshmallow in the 2013 unit and works fine. All you need to root it is a Mac, Win 8.1 PC or a linux the Java 7 SDK and the proper OS. Download it anyhow as Jave/Oracle is going to stop giving it away except for the simply non developmental Java.  Rooting allows you to pick exactly what Operating System goes in and you can remove pesky Android and Verizon or ATT programs. This is the 2013 model for bwifi only. Runs great price is rite. After looking at many tablets and hours of research I decided to buy this tablet and I couldn't be happier. If your an average person like me looking for a great tablet at budget price then this tablet is hard to beat. It might not have the latest or the greatest hardware but it's a Nexus device so you can upgrade to Marshmallow right away which means you'll have Google's latest software shortly after opening the package. If your a power user and need the newest and the best technology then this tablet might not be for you but if your an average person looking for a great tablet that won't break the bank then this tablet has more than enough power and features to keep you happy. The screen is bright and beautiful. The battery life and speakers are very good. The is processor is very quick and snappy with little to no lag and 2GB's of RAM means you'll be able to do plenty of multitasking. There are many similarly priced tablets but most only have 1GB of RAM. That 2nd GB or RAM definitely makes a difference.

There are some cons with this tablet. The camera is not that great but most camera's on tablets aren't. It also does not have a slot for an SD card so there is no expandable storage but these are things I can easily live with. If you look at all the specs you get for the price it's easy to see this tablet is an amazing value and an excellent buy.

Really like my Asus Nexus 7 2013 except for 2 annoying problems. One, I have not been able to find a case for it that does not disrupt the GPS. The cases all have magnets that render apps which need GPS, including compass, and astronomy apps, useless. Still hoping I can find a case that will work and, in any event, this is more a complaint about the cases than the Nexus. The other problem is about the microphone. It is far too easy to overdrive and distort the microphone, and there is apparently no way to adjust the gain even with third party apps. Also, there is no microphone input so there is no easy way to use an external mic, although I've seen some schemes where it may be possible to jerry rig an ext. mic thru the usb input. This is a major problem for me since I am a music teacher. I hope google is working on a solution for this. The iphones I've worked with have far superior microphones.

I am not saying this 7 is water proof. But it definitely tight. One time I left the Nexus 7 (2013) (in this Poetic Slimline Series case, http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E5NOXM4?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00) on top of my car on my way out to work on a rainy day. The 7 ended up on the road side. I found it > 2 hrs submerged in almost 1/2 of water. I blow dried the 7 for a day and kept it very warm for another day to make sure all water is dried. It fired right up and last another before the touch screen stop responding, while everything else still works. I end up changing the main board ribbon which was corroded. In the process I took everything apart and checked. There was no corrosion other that on that single ribbon's ends. An now, the 7 is fully functional again. That goes to say the qualify of the tablet and the protection of the case.

This is a solid, reliable tablet for the price. I have previously owned Asus products, including the aging Transformer TF300T, which this tablet was purchased to replace. Overall, Asus knew what they were doing.

Once I received this tablet, right out of the gate I installed Kali Linux Nethunter (which has native images for this tablet - this was part of the reason I chose the 7 - the other being it was pure Android and fairly compact) - after about a day or so of finagling with a number of root toolkits and image flashing, I finally got Kali working on it. After a little more testing, I discovered the Nexus 7's wireless adapter does not support monitor mode or injection, however, since the Lollipop-based Kali kernel natively supports both USB OTG and Y-Cables, I just grabbed a cheap TP-LINK TL-WN722N to connect externally for wireless penetration testing. While the adapter hasn't arrived yet, I'm confident it will work very well.

Plus, I won't be using it for this all of the time, so it's really not a big deal to have an external adapter.

This is really not enough to dock a star, as it's something most people won't even bother with - and for everything else I use it for (mobile gaming, web browsing, social networking), the Nexus 7 is miles ahead of the competition, as well as my old TF300T. I highly recommend this tablet for anyone, especially the tech-savvy like me. It's small, powerful, and fits my hands perfectly.

Basically, if you're looking for a 7-inch tablet for just about any purpose, your search has ended here :)

So far I really like the nexus... I was really annoyed with not being able to move the "recent google play items will appear here" thing until I found out... I could.  Lawls once I got used to this thing I loved it.

Things I like about the Nexus 7 (2013+ model):
No crashing/freezing
Responsive - Apps populate and screens switch rapidly.
Desktop Customization - Google has a few things preloaded, but I could move or remove anything I wanted from the home screen.
Design - The front is pretty much solid glass, so there is no indentation for the screen like on some ereaders and tablets.  The back has a soft rubberized feel that I personally like.

Things that I didn't like:
Speakers - Issued at mid and higher volumes.
Closing Programs - As I am new to android it was not immediately clear if programs where closing when I went back to home screen or staying up in the background and using resources.  I wish there was more clarity on this, but perhaps there is a task list I have not found yet.  Either way this is more android then Nexus, but in all fairness Nexus is running android... so yeah.

Final thoughts:

The reason I decided to buy the 2013 Nexus 7 is that bases on reviews it appeared some of the other newer, and more expensive tablets tend to hang or freeze while the 2013 Nexus 7 seemed from the reviews to be stable.  I owned two kobo glo's that had this problem and found it frustrating.  I built my own computer and am a bit spoiled when it comes to responsive technology.  In this regard I have not been disappointed by the Nexus 7 at all.  Unless you need the hardware for gaming, or a larger screen size, the Nexus 7 very likely will be all you need or want in a tablet and then some.

By biggest complaint is that the speakers tend to distort/buzz a little at medium and higher volume levels.  This is very noticeable when playing Netflix movies and often plug in $5 earbuds to "improve" the sound experience. I likely have a bad Nexus and plan to talk to a customer service on this soon.

Quick Update: Had 2 new Nexus 7's come in, and both had quality issues as well...  One had a strong patch of light bleed in the corner, and had grounding issues; The other had pretty strong light bleed around the entire screen, and line bleeding on 1/4 of the screen, visible in darker colors, or darker scenes of videos.  This is just upsetting...  Going to try to see if I can pick the best one of the lot, don't want the accessories to go to waste...

Starting off with the problems:

The used Nexus 7 I bought that was intended for myself had pretty bad light bleed, a small screen discoloration, and every now and then, a blue pixel or 2 liked to get stuck.  Did not test this tablet any further to figure out any other flaws,  this Nexus 7 is going to be returned.

The Nexus 7 I bought for my mom as a gift did not have any problems with the screen, besides very little light bleed that would be unnoticable in normal usage, but it has another issue that has cursed a lot of Nexus 7 owners, some might be unaware of this issue on their own Nexus 7  Grounding issues  If you suffer from horrible grounding issue, the Nexus 7 will have a tough time detecting those quick single finger touches if the tablet is on a table, bed, or a case, however if you are holding the tablet in your palms, or have multiple fingers touching it, this issue will go unnoticed.

Now, as of right now, the positives are overshadowed for the Nexus 7, but here they are anyways:

Now, if you don't have any screen defects, this is heck of a display, crisp and clear. The screen resolution of 1920x1080(323 ppi) is great for the price, and works great on a 7 inch tablet, the colors are pretty nice, although, I find the display to be just a touch on the greener side, and sadly, the only way to properly adjust the screen color is being rooted, and running a custom kernel.

The performance of the tablet is very smooth, after updating it to Android Marshmallow, browsing through apps, web pages, and u.i. was very smooth.  The Snapdragon S4 pro, along with the Adreno 320 should still be plenty of power for those who use the tablet for media consumption, web browsing, and most games, although power might be a little lacking for most recent major app games, but who cares, who does hardcore gaming on a general tablet?

The build quality and looks of this tablet are really nice, it feels solid in the hands, and doesnt feel like its going to break in your hands.  For the looks, it depends on your taste though, but I think it looks sharp, and simple.  Compared to the original Nexus 7, I felt like this Nexus 7 was not as comfortable to hold, it felt sharper on the edges, and less curved, however, its not as heavy for those long periods of usage.

Common issues people have had around the web, and other reviews regarding the Nexus 7:

Horrible light bleeding, stuck pixels, grounding issues, multi touch issues, phantom touches, softbricked from OEM software updates.

Personal opinion:

As of right now, I have a sour taste with Asus products, and the Nexus program currently.  The original Nexus 7 I have is still carrying on, but those had a good amount of issues as well  Asus has proven that their quality, and control of products have been rocky at best; from tablets, to phones, to GPU aftermarket designs, to motherboards, they make hit and miss products, which is pretty disheartening as they are a major supplier for electronics in the current world.  Hopefully the Nexus 7 in the mail will be free of issues, and make use of the few accessories I have for it, so my mum could have a nice Christmas present...

This is our second Nexus.  Absolutely just love it!!!!
After a ton of research, my tech hubby decided the newest version of the Nexus still meet our needs the best.  We've only had this one 3 months, but so far so good.
Our old Nexus experience:
The first nexus we bought survived my sons' toddlerhood very well!.  My husband bought it two and a half years ago for reading in bed.  Our son had just turned two.  And within days, the boy had claimed it as his own.  In those 2.5 years, my son dropped the tablet upwards of a dozen times a day.  Not exaggerating.  And he's 'a rough' kid too and it only had a cheap case to protecting it.  But eventually, the outdated software caused too many problems with the latest apps, frustrating both our son and me.  So we decided it was time for a new one for our son, who was now 4 and a half years old.  My husband wiped the old Nexus clean and it did help speed it up quite a bit... so it is now perfect for our 18month old daughter, since toddler apps don't require much space or the latest software.  She can't really "play" any of the apps yet.  All she really can do at this age is "color" on it.... but she's had the old one for three months and beats the ever loving cr*p out of it on a daily basis... and it's still going strong.  There isn't a scratch on the screen.  IDK, I'm just very impressed with Nexus, seeing as how every time one of my adult friends drop their iPhone, I see them ranting on facebook about how it shattered instantly.

The Nexus 7 (2013) is a great little 7" tablet. When I first saw the Nexus 7 back when they were new I felt it was too small. More recently I got my hands on one of as friends and started using it and found that it's actually not bad at all for quick browsing, e-reading, and playing most games. It was good enough that when Newegg and Amazon had a sale on bran dnew ones (which are generally hard to come by) I snapped one up. They are easy to unlock and relatively easy to root, so you can install a custom version of Android and run whatever apps you want if that's your thing, or you can stick with stock Android, and you still get to enjoy the latest Google has to offer as they've released Lollipop for the Nexus 7.

The only real downside I see is the limited storage space. Having only 16GB means you can't store a lot of larger files, so if you have a lot of apps, use emulators, and/or like to have a lot of music, the Nexus 7 will hamper you a bit.

It worked great for the first few months.  Then started having issues with the touch screen.  Then the charging port went bad and I had to send it to ASUS for repair. Also, the charging port that got replaced is going bad again.  This tablet would get five stars if it actually worked properly.

If you are reading this review please consider this as a significant review, as i have had this tablet for 2 years now and the issues i had with it are not just subject to my own handling of the device but are of the tablet in general.
I do agree that the hardware on the tablet is excellent and it does run fast but only on apps. I find myself constantly dealing with glitchy interface and lag in transition from apps. The OS is constantly poorly optimized for the tablet.
My biggest issue is the cheapness of the screen. This is poorly mentioned by users of the tablet even when i have noticed this within only a couple months of using it. The screen glass is cheap and will break very easily. I don't know how to describe this but some parts of the screen wear off and looks like its peeling, losing its glossyness, leaving splotches of wear all over the screen that look like they can be cleaned off. I decided to write this review because i recently broke my screen but just from carrying it in my pocket. I did not bump it on anything but just simple small pressures in the right areas cracked it. Very weak glass. Also, it was a small crack but the touch screen did not work well anymore to the point that i could not use it at all.

I had very good uses for this tablet and even considering what i disliked about it i still used it almost everyday. The only reason why i have such a problem with it is because of the price and well liking of the public of this tablet. It does not live up to its standards and the price is not considered cheap anymore for this quality. I believe there are much better tablets that could be bought with this price range. Please just don't look at the good reviews of a product, and compare between products yourself to check specific details such as the type of screen glass and the overall wear over time. The overall satisfaction of users will not tell you the issues you might face along the road.

DO NOT BUY ASUS!!!  I bought this tablet for my son for Christmas 2014.  At first it was a great tablet.  My son dropped it and put a very small crack in the LCD but yet the tablet still worked.  Eventually the tablet stopped charging.  This is when I contacted ASUS support and they informed me that I could mail the tablet back to their factory to have it fixed since it is still under their one year manufacturers warranty.  They received the tablet and immediately sent me an invoice for $205.00 to repair it.  They said that although it is still under the manufacturers warranty they cannot proceed to fix the charging port because the LCD was cracked.  I disputed the invoice and over and over they told me that they would not fix the charging port until they received payment to fix the LCD.  I explained to them that I did not want the LCD fixed, I only wanted the charge port fixed.  No where in their warranty does it state that they have to fix the LCD prior to fixing a warranted part.  ASUS is terrible with customer service and I now have a tablet that is less than a year old that is worthless.  Not only would they NOT fix the warranted part, but they wanted $205.00 to repair a tablet that only cost $179.00 originally.  I wonder if there are people out there that would actually pay that amount to get a tablet fixed when they could get a new one for less?  I'm not the one!

1. I first called Google tech support as it was the number provided on the device.  On a Saturday evening, my call was answered promptly.  Kudos to Google.
2. The Google rep was courteous.  We spent at least 20 minutes trying to figure out the serials number.  I got the sense the rep didn't believe  the serial number wasn't on the setting page, nor was it on the back of the device.  It turned out, I had to hold both the volume button and the power button down to go to the recovery mode to see the serial # buried in a list of things that made no sense to most common folks.
3. The google rep then advised me that I had to contact ASUS because the device wasn't bought from Google.
4. All in all, I spent 10 minutes waiting for ASUS to respond to the call and another one hour to restart the device.  This ASUS tech also didn't believe me when I told him  the serial # wasn't on the back of the device.  To be honest, if I didn't physically look at it, I wouldn't believe  gogole/auss would not put the serial # on the back of the device either.
5.at the end, both the ASUS tech and me were tired.  He put me on hold, then came back and said I needed to send it in to be fixed.  The estimated cost is $300.  Well, thank you but no thanks.  I can get a new Nexus 7 for $149 on Amazon.  I could get a Nexus 9 for less than $400.  Not to mention the original cost of my Nexus 7 was less than $230  :-)))

As much as I like the Asus 7, it does have one fatal flaw: battery drain. I charged mine up to 90%, went to  bed, and 10 hours later the battery was down to 60%. Keep in mind the tablet was turned OFF! No use! This is a long standing problem with the Google OS and the internet is filled with complaints. My other tablets like the Sero 7 Pro don't have this problem. Charge to 90%, go to bed, 10 hours later I'm at 90% or 89%. This has been a problem with every Google OS from Jelly Bean, through KitKat, and on into Lollipop. Google knows about this problem but has been unwilling to fix it. Search the internet for "KitKat battery drain" and you'll find hundreds of thousands of people that find the device unusable because of this problem. If you have one of these devices and you don't have the battery drain problem, DO NOT UPDATE the OS. This is when the problem occurs. Until the battery drain problem is fixed, I cannot recommend this tablet to anyone.

Let me preface this by saying that the Nexus 7, when working, is an OK tablet. The screen image is crisp, it is slick and thin, and the apps load quickly. There are some problems with apps crashing, and the screen is not always responsive to finger touch, however, this is not my main complaint.

I have owned two Nexus 7 tablets over the course of just over two years. I bought the original Nexus 7 tablet for work and after about 6 months I started to have frequent freezes during the boot screen which, according to forums online, was a common problem for many users. I called ASUS since it was still under warranty and, although there was no external damage, they refused to honor the warranty without extravagant repair fees. I found some workarounds online which required forcing a reset on the tablet to get it working again temporarily. Eventually after about 8 more months and several more of these forced resets, the tablet stopped turning on altogether and I decided it was easier to just buy a new one instead of trying to repair the old tablet any longer.

I got the new version of the Nexus 7 in September 2014, about 10 months ago. I use the tablet exclusively at work for reference apps and email and am extremely careful with it as a delicate piece of hardware. At work recently, the screen cracked with NO DAMAGE to the tablet just from carrying it in a loose pocket about 200 feet to my car. Although I did not drop it, bump it, or otherwise cause any significant trauma, there was a crack in the screen which prevented the screen from registering touch any longer. I read online that this has happened to many people besides myself. Again I called ASUS and the customer service was completely unwilling to help and offered an insulting repair cost of $350 for a tablet which I purchased originally for $200.

Although the Nexus 7 is a cheap tablet with great specs, there are obviously shortcuts being taken with the integrity of its construction. I will never buy another ASUS tablet again because of their lackadaisical approach to customer service. I would warn people who are considering this tablet that, despite the price, you get what you pay for. These tablets seem built to last 8-12 months, even with minimal use and careful handling.

I bought this to essentially replace my old laptop with something smaller and lighter, but still bigger than a smartphone and stronger. For the price, this is a stellar buy. I've been using mine daily at work (I work graveyard shift). It is a fast and reliable device that has respectable battery life, even when running power intensive apps like Hearthstone. It's nicer than my smartphone in that it can switch between apps that are running at the same time very efficiently. The screen is crystal clear, nicer than my Galaxy 3, and worlds nicer than Nintendo 3DS. Perfect for watching Netflix or Crunchyroll or Youtube. I am very impressed by the speakers as well, it can get quite loud and doesn't distort the music by doing so. If you already have an android device and google account, you will be able to get used to using this device in minutes. Mine updated to the latest version of Android right away and I love it.

The only negative things I can say about it are nitpicks really. I wish the home button was a physical button on the screen that I could press to wake the screen up. When the screen goes dark you only have the lock/power button. Not a big deal, just something I don't care for.

If you want an affordable tablet that can run most every app, but you don't want to drop 500+ on the latest model, this is an excellent choice.

We purchased this device because we needed something running Android for data collection tools we are developing at work. It definitely meets those needs, despite many annoying errors when you need to have multiple users and accounts linked to one device.

We also have an IPad, so I'll leave a couple comments for those folks who might be wondering which to buy for home use.  I find the IPad much more user friendly, and less cluttered with aps you'll never use. Settings are not easy to navigate on the nexus, and it's especially hard to find those settings Which place some limits on the data Google collects and stores on your internet usage. If you need secure email, I'm not sure this device is a good choice as it probably opens your other (non gmail) accounts to goggle data mining if you route through their gmail Ap, but I'm just assuming this. Same for storage of things on their cloud (Google drive), so read their privacy policies carefully if you are using this for work and be careful what you enable on the device. The IPad is miles ahead with regard to screen resolution and camera. I only use this for work, so have not tried out any of the steaming services, third party aps, etc, so cannot comment on those.  Buttons (on/off and volume) are somewhat hard to press, and become more difficult when the device is placed in a case. Downloading updates and installing seemed really slow compared to IOS. Overall,  this device seems quite clunky in comparison to the IPad.

I had the 32GB Nexus 7 for just over two years and loved it. When it died (I think the power port is damaged), I bought this 16GB Nexus 7 as a replacement. It is awful. I mean, it's beautiful and slim and light and works just like the old Nexus I had. Except... it freezes and restarts between five and fifty times a day - no warning, no (observable) reason - it just stops.

I've tried everything to get it to stop that. I've reset it to factory settings/etc., I've deleted all apps, I've tried using it with only one app open... and it still freezes and restarts. For anyone who might think I must be using some crazy app that's taking up memory/processing space: the app I have open most often when it freezes is either Google's HangOut or Google's gDocs. For a day or two, I thought maybe interaction with my home wi-fi was the issue, but then this morning it was on my office wi-fi and it froze and restarted.

I've Googled the issue, but Google itself seems to be of no help. The search brings up forums where folks discuss this issue and, like me, they've tried everything (those forums are where I learned how to reset to factory settings, stop it from automatically downloading app upgrades, etc.). The consensus on the forums seems to be that the 16GB version of the Nexus has a hardware issue that causes this. Not every single one of the version - just random individual devices have the problem. I got a dud, it seems.

I'm returning it to Amazon - they've said they'll issue a full refund. So, here's hoping! I'm unsure whether I'm going to risk going with another 32GB Nexus 7 or move on to some other maker's tablet.

This device, though, has just been so disappointing.

UPDATE: 7/6/2015
After a week or two of my Nexus 7 2013 tablet freezing and rebooting, I did some research about restoring it to kitkat 4.4.4.  I first worked on my 2012 model and after some issue using the flashall.bat, I was able to get it restored to 4.4.4.  So I then started on my 2013 model. After a whole day of trying to get it to boot using 4.4.4, I was about to give up when I found an article that said there is an issue with certain models recently manufactured and the boot.img which prevents it from being restored to 4.4.4.  There is hacked fix for this, but it is not certified, so I did not want to use it. So I went back to the official Google site that has the factory images and noticed there was a brand new 5.1.1. image. I was able to get my 2013 tablet restored to it.  Now the strangest thing is so far the 2013 tablet has not reboot or frozen since restored to the new 5.1.1 image.  A couple times on a few sites Chrome would start to freeze, but then after a second or two would continue.  All that said and reported there still seems to be a very huge issue with Nexus 2013 tablets and Android 5. XX.  Just do a search for Nexus 7 2013 bricked and read all of the posts.

The design is great and the features are great, but with Android 5.xx it is useless. The tablet freezes several times a day and reboots even if it is just sitting there with no app active. I ordered this one expecting it would come with Android 4.4, because my 2012 one became useless when upgraded to Android 5.0.  This 2013 version came with Android 5.0 and immediately wanted to upgrade to 5.1.  I gave it a try and sure enough it started freezing up and rebooting as well.  I have tried the clear cache routine several times and also remove any app that is not ready for Android 5.0. One of the apps that freezes more than any is Chrome.

Also had problems with the GPS which I did not have with the 2012 version.  I have the Samsung S4 smartphone which now wants to be upgraded to Android 5.0 which is not going to happen if I can help it.

Biggest waste of money ever.  This tablet is junk.  It starts out speedy and responsive. After time it becomes ice age slow, unresponsive and freezes or reboots.  Ironically, the worst app for this is Chrome and Facebook.  Save yourself the money and the headache and get an iPad.

First off, let me say that this is a fantastic device. I would actually rate it 5 stars if there wasn't one huge issue. The charging port. No problems after a year and a half. If you need to return it for warranty repairs they do not cover shipping. You must pay to ship and insure it yourself. Also, after the repair you have 3 months warranty and then it is over. One of ours went back and they lost it. It took well over a month to get it back. Then the charging port broke 3 1/2 months after we got it back and they refused to cover it. So, again, I have sent it back and now I wait for them to repair it and I have to pay for the repair myself. So, my best advice is to buy this device but also buy a QI compatible wireless charger for it. Then I can give it 5 stars.

I bought a Nexus 7 for my son based on the positive reviews I read on-line.  My experience with the tablet and ASUS has been anything but positive.  I will say that the tablet worked fine for all of 6 months!  At that time the cheap charging port broke on the tablet.  I had the exact same thing happen on a $60 Coby tablet I had bought years earlier.  I thought for the extra money I was buying something constructed better - obviously I was mistaken.  So I thought no problem I will send it to ASUS and they can repair the charging port under warranty.  After getting the run around for a couple of weeks they tell me that the battery, some board in the tablet, and the charging port are all bad and they can repair it for $75.  Said none of it is covered due to customer caused damage!  First, the tablet had never been dropped and second when is the last time a drop would break a battery?  This is a real clever trick to just make everything out to be customer caused damage and they never have to take responsibility for their cheaply made tablet.  If you can guarantee that nothing is going to break it might be worth the chance otherwise I would steer clear of this product.

Is there any support or troubleshooting option?  Who will help if there's an issue?  I am a really basic user,  no games,  primarily email and watching a movie now and then.
I purchased the original Nexus Tablet. After 11 months it started freezing on the start screen.  I've tried over 6 months, now it became a challenge to me,  to resolve the issues and learned my only option was to mail it in ASUS.
I called Google, they were quick to tell me they don't offer technical support and forwarded me to Nexus.  Nexus said that along with Google, they had nothing to do with the manufacturing of this product, even though there name was clearly imprinted on the back.
They gave me the number to ASUS who is the actual manufacturer.  After doing some trouble shooting, ASUS determined that I was having the same issue others Nexus 7 Tablet users were having.  My only option was to mail it in and have the motherboard replaced, that would cost around $225 plus the cost of shipping.  After learning this, I went back to the big box retailer I purchased it from and learned that sending it in was my only option. They offered to pay for the shipping however the cost of the new motherboard was up to me.  I asked how they knew it was the motherboard, I was told,  "that's usually the problems with that tablet.  He couldn't count how many they had to send back and of course when they called the customer to tell them the approximate cost of the repair,  he didn't know of a single customer that accepted that.
Of course I said no.  I  didn't pay that much for the tablet to begin with.

Probably one of the finest computers ever made.  A pity they discontinued it.  It has blinding speed, and an incredibly dense screen (1920 x 1200 resolution and 323 ppi pixel density).  THE BEST part of it is that it apparently has 12 GB for apps, not just 2 GB as you would think since its RAM is only 2 GB!  THERE IS A LOT of nonsense on the Web about how the lack of an SD card is a problem.  It isn't.  You just substitute a flash drive.  You just plug the tablet into a PC through the USB micro to USB cord supplied, and you can connect to the flash drive through the PC!  (Or you can just use the PC for extra storage.)  The critics also complain of the camera's poor light sensitivity.  Actually, you can use the "Fill Light" function in Picasa or other photo editor to adjust the light level after the fact.  As to the supposedly grainy texture of the photos from the rear camera, I suppose that is the case, based on limited testing.  However, I independently bought a $25 camera that is as good as any tablet camera out there.  Therefore I don't mind.  Yet another good point is that it charges while it is connected to the USB on your PC.  (Many tablets don't.)  The only thing I have not liked so far after using it for about 4 days is that the cord, which is used for charging and for USB connection, is flimsy.  Mine lasted only 4 days.  A replacement, USB A male to micro USB B male, is a standard type, and can be bought inexpensively.  If you don't trust your cord, it is a good idea to keep a replacement cord handy.

The only thing is I wish the camera had zoom, or if it does I haven't been able to find it, and it seems like I am needing it all the time (I don't have a regular camera).  The camera can take panoramas though and also has a neat feature called photo sphere that can take a 360 degree picture you can then view as a video.  Pretty cool.  I haven't been able to find out how to share it with anyone though.

I use this tablet quite a lot for many things everyday and am real happy with it.

Update:  Well, I figured out how to zoom when using the camera.  Just have to stretch the screen like when you zoom a webpage and pinch again to pan back.  Still learning, ha.

I have been using these tablets for several years for a tablet/mobile-based research project. They are easy to use, work well, have decent battery life, and are decently portable. I have had no issues with these tablets working in very harsh conditions - so they do have a bit of ruggedness to them, and the price point is very good despite being a bit older product overall.

I love this tablet! I got it as a Christmas gift in 2013 and immediately started personalizing the background and icons with LineDeco. I downloaded several apps (44 right now!) for work and play and they work great with no low-storage problem- good since this tablet doesn't have a microsd slot.  Netflix looks fine to me and I like that I can cast the entire screen to my tv direct from the drop down menu.  The size is perfect for ebooks- even my small hands can hold it one-handed, as long as the case is off.  The camera takes great pictures.

I have had trouble with the touchscreen sensitivity where the tablet doesn't always register my swiping, but that could just be me.  About year 3 the charging port stopped working but I bought a wireless charging pad and that has worked fairly well although not with the case on and it sometimes loses 'connection' when I'm charging overnight and it won't be fully charged in the morning.. Now I'm in year 5 and the tablet is definitely showing it's age (although so am I!). It lags when switching between apps and is slow loading updates on Facebook.  Occasionally it will freeze completely and then restart itself.

Wish Google had kept this line going! I tried Samsung Galaxy Tab A 7 and it was not worthy. Now I'm looking for something decent to replace this guy.
